resource.chars:
The Systeme of the world, as it is now understood,
is taken to occupy the whole <u>Abysse <\u> of <u>Space <\u>, and 
to be as such actually infinite, and the appearance 
of the sphere of fixt starrs, still discovring smaller 
and smaller <s>bodies <\s> <s>starrs <\s> ones, as you apply better Telescopes,
seems to confirm this doctrine. And indeed, were the whole 
system finite, it, though never so extended wod 
still occupy no part of the <u>infinitum <\u> of space, which 
necessarily and evidently exists; whence the whole 
would be surrounded on all sides with an infinite 
<u>mane <\u>?, and the superficiall starrs would gravitate 
towards those near the center, and with an accelerated 
motion runn into them, and in process of time coalesce 
and unite with them into one. And supposing Time enough, this 
would be a necessary consequence. But if the whole 
be infinite, all the parts of it would be nearly <u>in aequilibrio<\u>
and consequently each fixt starr, being drawn by contra 
ry powers, would keep its place, or move, till such time,
as, from such an <u>aequilibrium <\u>, it found its resting place,
on <s>this <\s> which account the some perhaps may think the In 
finity of the Sphere of fixt starrs no very precarious 
postulate. But to this I find two objections, which are 
rather of a Metaphysicall than Physicall nature, and 
first, this supposes, as its consequent, that the number 
of fixt starrs is not only indefinite, but actually more 
than any finite number; which seems absurd <u>in terminis <\u>
all number being composed of Units, and no two [illegible]
or centers being at <s>any <\s> a distance more than finite.

The Systeme of the world, as it is now understood,
is taken to occupy the whole <u>Abysse <\u> of <u>Space <\u>, and 
to be as such actually infinite, and the appearance 
of the sphere of fixt starrs, still discovring smaller 
and smaller <s>bodies <\s> <s>starrs <\s> ones, as you apply better Telescopes,
seems to confirm this doctrine. And indeed, were the whole 
system finite, it, though never so extended wod 
still occupy no part of the <u>infinitum <\u> of space, which 
necessarily and evidently exists; whence the whole 
would be surrounded on all sides with an infinite 
<u>mane <\u>?, and the superficiall starrs would gravitate 
towards those near the center, and with an accelerated 
motion runn into them, and in process of time coalesce 
and unite with them into one. And supposing Time enough, this 
would be a necessary consequence. But if the whole 
be infinite, all the parts of it would be nearly <u>in aequilibrio<\u>
and consequently each fixt starr, being drawn by contra 
ry powers, would keep its place, or move, till such time,
as, from such an <u>aequilibrium <\u>, it found its resting place,
on <s>this <\s> which account the some perhaps may think the In 
finity of the Sphere of fixt starrs no very precarious 
postulate. But to this I find two objections, which are 
rather of a Metaphysicall than Physicall nature, and 
first, this supposes, as its consequent, that the number 
of fixt starrs is not only indefinite, but actually more 
than any finite number; which seems absurd <u>in terminis <\u>
all number being composed of Units, and no two points 
or centers being at <s>any <\s> a distance more than finite.
